description:
Agreia pratensis is a species of bacteria that belongs to the phylum Actinobacteria. It is a Gram-positive, non-spore-forming, and aerobic bacterium. Agreia pratensis was first isolated from a grassland soil sample collected in Germany.

The cells of Agreia pratensis are typically rod-shaped and can form short chains. They are motile, with the help of peritrichous flagella. The optimal growth temperature for this species is around 25-30Â°C, and it can grow in a pH range of 6.0-8.0.

Agreia pratensis is considered a soil-dwelling bacterium and is known to play a role in the decomposition of organic matter in grassland ecosystems. It has the ability to degrade various plant-derived polymers, such as cellulose and hemicellulose, making it an important contributor to the carbon cycle in its natural habitat.

Taxonomically, Agreia pratensis is classified within the family Microbacteriaceae, which is a family of actinobacteria commonly found in soil and other terrestrial environments. The genus Agreia was first proposed in 2001, and Agreia pratensis was described as a novel species in 2004.
